entry.title: Shell Script - Notifying When Directory Change
entry.content:
One of these days, I was needed to monitor a directory that constantly was modified. I had needed some way, get something that could notify me when the structure(file system) from directory was modified. So, I decided to write my own script, whose helped me with this task.

For it, I used the Linux stat utility, whose return information about a file.

Below, I show you like it works:

</p>

<h1>!/bin/bash</h1>

<p>LTIME=<code>stat -c %Z .</code></p>

<p>while true
do
        ATIME=<code>stat -c %Z .</code></p>

<pre><code>    if [[ "$ATIME" != "$LTIME" ]]
    then
            full_name=`/bin/ls | head -1`
            name=$(basename "$full_name")
            extension="${name##*.}"
            final_name="${name%.*}"

            if [ "$extension" == "txt" ]
            then
                    if [ ! -f $final_name.log ]
                    then
                            touch $final_name.log
                            echo "Modified ATIME" >> $final_name.log
                    fi
            fi
            LTIME=$ATIME
    fi
    sleep 5
</code></pre>

<p>done

So, the code above consists a script that verify if, a new file text was created in current directory. If it has been, then, it checks if already exists a file name called final_name.log, and case not exists, it will be create.

First all, we get the initial current time and we hold it inside variable LTIME. It variable will be setting just once.

LTIME=<code>stat -c %Z .</code>
